item.title: Tools for self-reflection: Tarot
item.description: We all feel the need to self-reflect. Leadership is all about self-reflection, exploring your perceptions and emotions. We might be caught in one interpretation of a situation and be unable to see clearly through the clutter to give it another interpretation. Tarot is one way to look at it differently. Lay the cards for a situation, look at them, interpret them and reflect if the interpretation indicated by the cards could be another explaination.

item.title: Journal rankings
item.description: Journals are not equal. Some are more relevant than others, and some have better quality. Journals also have an impact factor, which tells how often studies from this journal are cited in articles, relative to other journals. Details about the impact factor calculation are available from the calculators, such as Web of Science. A gap is closed by the Academic Journal Guide that publishes a ranking of journals and classifies them from 1 to 4+, where 4+ is the best ranking.

item.title: Power
item.description: Power is a corruptor, it corrupts people without their knowledge. According to Sturm and Antonakis (n.d.), “power is having the discretion and the means to asymmetrically enforce one’s will over others”. Moderator variables exist, which influence pro- and antisocial outcomes. A key in power is its assymetry. Having power needs subjects to exercise power on. Any power relation is therefore at least dyadic. Power relations can exist openly or in a concealed way.

item.title: Waterfall vs Agile
item.description: Recently, on LinkedIn, a contact of mine wrote an interesting article about Waterfall vs Agile. Malinowski’s article expresses the opinion and observation that, nowadays, people see Waterfall software delivery methodologies as bad and Agile practices as the saviour of us all. I share his observation. Actually, I’d go that far and say that we need to have waterfall methodologies in place to ensure software deliveries within certain boundaries. As an example, consider a project that needs to deliver a large functionality within a fixed timeframe and where delivery problems would lead to overrun on time.

item.title: What is management
item.description: My stance References My stance First things first, according to Dictionary.com (n.d.) the roots of manage date back to Italy and Latin. In its origin, manage stems from manege and means to train, lead, or walk with the horses. In the figurative sense, we could just replace horses with “X”, such as machines, events, humans, and we would end up with a nice picture of a manager training, leading, or running the subject under management.

item.title: Constructivism
item.description: My stance Social Constructivism Key terms in phenomenology My stance Having read about positivism and constructivism in a sociological context, I have become convinced that my attitude can be best described as constructivism. Positivism appears to be too rigid and too deterministic for sociological inquiries. My main critique with positivism is, it assumes experiment design and repeatability. While some social experiments do work and are repeatable, such as the well known experiment of a “sick” person collapsing on the street and analyzing the response of public, there are many more experiments that depend on many factors.

item.title: About
item.description: About me Hello, thanks for visiting my site on the internet. These pages are a personal view on management topics. I am a line manager in a large bank and pursue a Doctor of Business Administration. Of course, all expressed opinions and materials are unrelated to my employer and represent a very personal stance. Over the years, I have held various management positions, have spoken at various occasions and started and contributed to several open source software projects - some of my own projects reached a bit of fame.
